awd_titl_txt: Cross-cultural trust and resource sharing: The Role of Ideal Affect
awd_abstract_narration:
Trust is the basis of social coordination and cooperation, and considered by many to be the very foundation of high-functioning societies. Indeed, people share more with people whom they trust, and societies with higher levels of trust have more efficient judicial systems, higher quality government bureaucracies, less corruption, and are more economically developed. How do people decide whom to trust, especially when they need to make these decisions quickly, with very little information? Remarkably, little is known about the cues that people use to judge trustworthiness and how these cues might vary across cultures, despite the fact that these cues may critically determine whether people become friend or foe. This is especially important now because people are in greater contact with others whose cultural ideas and practices differ from their own. In the proposed project, Tsai and colleagues test the hypothesis that people trust and share more resources with others whose emotional expressions match how people ideally want to feel (their ideal affect). They predict that cultural differences in whom people trust and share resources with are due to cultural differences in how people ideally want to feel. This prediction is tested in three behavioral and three fMRI experiments, as well as a longitudinal study. These findings will provide insights about interpersonal trust in different cultures.

In previous work, we observed that members of North American cultures value excited states---excitement, enthusiasm, and elation---more, while members of East Asian cultures value calm states---calm, peacefulness, serenity---more. These cultural differences influenced whom people trusted and with whom they shared resources. European Americans trusted and gave more to people who showed excitement (vs. calm), whereas East Asians trusted and gave more to people who showed calm (vs. excitement). These findings demonstrate that people trust and give more to others whose emotional expressions match their ideal affect. This ideal affect match mattered even more than matches in race or sex, suggesting that emotional expressions may signal shared values even more than more static facial features.  In the proposed project, we use a variety of experimental, cross-cultural, and neuroimaging methods to examine whether situational factors (i.e., having time to deliberate; being in a good vs. bad mood; knowing someone's reputation) increase or decrease people's use of emotional cues to decide whom to trust and share with. In addition, using a longitudinal design, we examine whether these processes influence the development of trust and friendship while people are adjusting to new cultures -- specifically, Chinese studying in the U.S., and Americans studying in China. Together, these studies will: (1) advance understanding of how people decide whom to trust and share resources; (2) promote cross-cultural communication and exchange; and (3) increase awareness about the unconscious cultural biases that may result in discrimination against particular groups (e.g., bicultural Asian Americans) in multicultural societies like the U.S.

por.por_cntn:
Trust is the basis of many high functioning organizations and societies. But how do people know whom to trust, and does this vary across cultures? Understanding cultural similarities and differences in trust is critical to promoting cross-cultural communication and collaboration within and across countries. The overarching goal of this project was to examine the role of emotion in trust and resource sharing in the US and East Asia.

In previous research, we showed that the emotions that people value and ideally want to feel (their “ideal affect”) varies across cultures. European Americans value excitement, elation, and enthusiasm more than their East Asian counterparts. These differences influence whom people perceive as friendly and trustworthy and how they treat them: European Americans judge strangers who show big, toothy “excited” smiles as friendlier and more trustworthy, and they share more resources with them compared to East Asians. In contrast, East Asians share resources more with targets who show closed, “calm” smiles.

The project had three specific aims: (1) to examine the situational factors that may alter the influence of cultural differences in ideal affect on trust and resource sharing in US and East Asian (mainland China, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Korea, Japanese), using different behavioral economic games, (2) to examine the affective and social cognitive mechanisms that underlie cultural differences in trust and resource sharing, using neuroimaging methods, and (3) to examine the influence of ideal affect on the development of trust in more intimate social relationships, using surveys and content analyses of cultural products.

For the first aim, we conducted studies in which European Americans and East Asians (Chinese, Taiwanese) had to decide how much money to give or invest in excited, calm, and neutral targets, under different situations. In one series of studies, participants received information about targets’ reputations, which were either uncertain, good, or bad, before making their decisions. In another series of studies, participants either had to make their decisions quickly, or were given time to deliberate, and in a third series of studies, participants made their decisions after they were shown positive, negative, or neutral images. Across cultures, participants were more likely to give and invest in targets that matched their ideal affect when targets’ reputations were less certain, when participants had to make their decisions quickly, and when participants were not distracted by emotional images.

For the second aim, we conducted a neuroimaging study in which European Americans and Chinese had to decide which targets to trust and invest in after receiving information about targets’ reputations. Cultural differences emerged in the areas of brain activity that predicted investment: European Americans showed greater activity in brain areas associated with negative affect (anterior insula) when responding to targets with bad reputations, and across the targets, the more these areas were activated, the less European Americans invested in them. In contrast, East Asians showed greater activity in brain areas associated with positive responses (nucleus accumbens) to targets with good reputations, and the more these brain areas were activated, the more they invested in targets. These differences may reflect broader cultural differences in norms regarding trust: because European Americans generally trust strangers more, they may be focused on detecting the least trustworthy strangers, whereas because Chinese generally trust strangers less, they may be focused on identifying the most trustworthy strangers.

For the third aim, we conducted a series of studies examining European Americans and Japanese views of romantic partners and relationships. Consistent with the greater emphasis European Americans place on excitement, European Americans wanted their relationships to be more passionate and close than did Japanese, and they viewed a trusting relationship as one where partners were closer than did Japanese. In contrast, Japanese wanted their relationships to maintain appropriate distance more than US participants did. These differences were also reflected in the content of US and Japanese love songs and movie posters, supporting the idea that media promotes cultural ideas regarding emotion and love.

Together, these findings demonstrate how culture shapes trust of strangers and in close relationships, and the role that emotions play in these processes. The studies not only transform our scientific understanding of how culture shapes trust in social relationships through emotion, but also may serve as the basis for improved cross-cultural communication and interventions aimed at reducing cultural biases in various personal and applied settings.

The project had several broader impacts as well, including training students from a variety of under-represented backgrounds (e.g., first generation college students, Latin-x, Middle Eastern students, international students from mainland China, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Korea). We have also presented this work to a broad range of academic and public audiences world-wide.
